name: treatment of used beverage cans, for recycling, unsorted, sorting
product: aluminium scrap, post-consumer, prepared for melting
description:
This activity represents the treatment of used beverage cans (UBCs) from separate collection, i.e., a source-segregated municipal solid waste fraction, through sorting for recycling. The sorting of 'used beverage cans' yields 'aluminium scrap, post-consumer, prepared for melting' which is typically used for the production of aluminium, wrought alloy (Haupt et al. (2018)). 
Source: 
Melanie Haupt, Thomas Kägi, Stefanie Hellweg, Life cycle inventories of waste management processes, Data in Brief, Volume 19, 2018, Pages 1441-1457, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dib.2018.05.067.
Geography:  Europe without Switzerland
Technology:  Technology encountered in Europe without Switzerland for the underlying time frame.
Time period:  Data assumed representative of the situation in Europe without Switzerland in 2012.

name: market for electricity, high voltage, aluminium industry
description:
This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.
This dataset describes the electricity available on the high voltage level for the Oceania primary aluminium-industry, i.e. used for primary aluminium production. Aluminium industry specific markets are needed in an LCI database because primary aluminium production is very energy intensive, and hence the location of production plants is often determined by access to large amounts of cheap electricity, which often results in an electricity mix that is different from the general grid mix of the countries where the production plants are located.
Geography:  Aluminium producing Oceania countries (AU, NZ)
Technology:  Average technology used to transmit and distribute electricity. Includes underground and overhead lines.

name: treatment of salt tailing from potash mine, residual material landfill
description:
This dataset represents the activity of waste disposal of 'salt tailing from potash mine' in a residual material landfill (RMLF). Recommended use of this dataset: The waste are non-target salts and minerals separated during the mining and refining of potash (KCO3, KOH).  Inventoried waste consists of fraction: 100% salt tailings potash mining; .  Waste composition (wet, in ppmw): H2O na; O 98835; H na; C na; S 49521; N na; P na; B na; Cl 498570; Br na; F na; I na; Ag na; As na; Ba na; Cd na; Co na; Cr na; Cu na; Hg na; Mn na; Mo na; Ni na; Pb na; Sb na; Se na; Sn na; V na; Zn na; Be na; Sc na; Sr na; Ti na; Tl na; W na; Si na; Fe na; Ca 8241.3; Al na; K 6363.9; Mg 47830; Na 290630.  Share of carbon in initial waste input that is biogenic 61.4%. 
Geography:  This dataset represents a landfill site with mean annual temperature (MAT) of 6.5 degC, mean annual precipitation (MAP) of 920 mm/year, mean annual actual evaporation (EAT) of 326 mm/year, and net infiltration of 594 mm/year. Temperature at site can result in permafrost conditions, which slows down water flow by a factor of 0.998. The leachate percolating through the residual material landfill has an average residence time of 5.9 years.
Reference for climatic parameters:
World Bank, 2022. Average precipitation in depth (mm per year), World Bank Group Available at: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/AG.LND.PRCP.MM?end=2019&start=2019
Environment Canada. Meteorological Service of Canada. Canadian Climate Normal Available at:https://climate.weather.gc.ca/climate_normals/index_e.html
Technology:  Residual material landfill for polluted, inorganic waste (VVEA Type C). With base seal and leachate collection system. Ultimate average landfill height is 10 meters. Operation phase duration is 30 years. Recultivation after closure. No additional solidification with cement requested. Based on average waste composition and climate data the end of carbonate phase in the residual material landfill is estimated to be reached after 60 000 years.

name: treatment of sulfidic tailings, from nickel mine operation, tailings impoundment
product: sulfidic tailings, from nickel mine operation
description:
This dataset represents the activity of waste disposal of sulfidic tailings, from nickel mine operation in a tailings impoundment. 
Background: Tailings, a waste material produced during mineral concentration (beneficiation), often contain significant quantities of mobile toxic metals and are typically produced in large quantities. To manage these wastes, tailings are commonly stored behind dammed impoundments, known as tailings ponds. These ponds pose a significant long-term pollution risk as metals may leach out into the surrounding environment, potentially over very long timeframes.
Modelling approach: This dataset was produced using a model developed specifically for assessing the long-term emissions of tailings disposal (see Doka, 2017). The tailings disposal model is based on the modelling framework applied in existing landfill process models used in ecoinvent and is based on a top-down approach. Literature data on measurements of deposited tailings compositions (solids) and measured current concentrations in leachate (liquid) form the basis of the model and are used to characterise pollutant mobility and calculate the currently occurring rate of emissions of the landfill. Heeding chief parameters, such as hydrology, pH development and elemental chemistry, these emissions are then projected into the future. Tailings composition is based on the typical composition of tailings at nickel mine sites worldwide; i.e. composition is not region-specific. Land use was calculated following the approach described by Doka (2008). Based on an assumed generic final height of a tailings impoundment of 60 m and an assumed tailings density of 2200 kg/m3, a land area of 7.58E-06 m2 is required per kilogram of sulfidic tailings. The land is assumed to be converted from unknown origin to a disposal site. After an operational phase of 30 years, spontaneous restoration of a consolidated state is assumed to be reached after one hundred years. The total occupation time is therefore 130 years and the land occupation per kilogram tailings is 9.85E-04 m2.
Waste composition (wet, in ppm): H2O 300000; O 623400; H na; C 6145; S 359.53; N 5.0454; P 223.04; B 54.583; Cl 102.61; Br 0.22894; F 772.88; I na; Ag 8.5672; As 54.876; Ba 349.73; Cd 4.2073; Co 14.437; Cr 55.949; Cu 649.95; Hg 0.26107; Mn 191.27; Mo 11.985; Ni 730.27; Pb 164.15; Sb 28.927; Se 6.5496; Sn 27.855; V 127.15; Zn 232.03; Be 1.1555; Sc 12.867; Sr 98.34; Ti 227.57; Tl 2.8558; W 9.9784; Si 37291; Fe 10762; Ca 3218.1; Al 10317; K 1762.7; Mg 1565.1; Na 1013.   //  Share of carbon in waste that is biogenic 0%.
Activity extent: The dataset includes all potential emissions to the environment and land use changes. Input exchanges of infrastructure, materials, energy, and water are not included here but are accounted for in the activity, nickel mine operation.
References
Doka, G. (2008). Life Cycle Inventory data of mining waste: Emissions from sulfidic tailings disposal. Zürich, Switzerland: Doka Life Cycle Assessments.
Doka, G. (2017). A model for waste-specific and climate-specific life cycle inventories of tailings impoundments. Zürich, Switzerland: Doka Life Cycle Assessments.
Geography:  Given name of site is 'Nickel deposits; Global'. Impoundment site with mean annual temperature (MAT) of 1.78652028580185 degC, mean annual precipitation (MAP) of 642.411142680601 mm/year, mean annual actual evaporation (EAT) of 248.065946276104 mm/year, and net infiltration of 518.378169542549 mm/year (using half of natural surface evapotranspiration). 
Temperature at site can result in permafrost conditions, which slows down water flow by a factor of 0.994. 
Technology:  This is an inventory for an impoundment of copper ore beneficiation tailings waste. The following assumptions were made concerning technology: final impoundment height is 60 meters; operation phase duration is 30 years; and impoundment leachates are released into the environment untreated.
Time period:  'Data on average composition of tailings and tailings-derived leachates from literature sources published between 1994 and 2017 (mean publication date: 2009±6). Mean annual temperature and precipitation data for 1970-2000 (source: Fick and Hijmans, 2017); mean annual evapotranspiration for 1950-2000 (source: Fekete et al., 2002). Production volume based on world mine production data from the USGS Minerals Yearbook 2015. Transfer coefficients from prospective, tailings-specific model. 
References: 
Fekete, B. M., Vorosmarty, C. J. & Grabs, W. (2002). High-resolution fields of global runoff combining observed river discharge and simulated water balances. Global Biogeochemical Cycles, 16, 15-1 - 15-10.
Fick, S. E. & Hijmans, R. J. (2017). Worldclim 2: New 1-km spatial resolution climate surfaces for global land areas. International Journal of Climatology, 37, 4302-4315.'

name: uranium production, centrifuge, enriched 4.0%
product: uranium, enriched 4.0%, per separative work unit
description:
This module uses a mix of data, some specific for the URENCO facilities taken from environmental reports, some from literature. Due to lack of information on Russian plants, all requirements and emissions are arbitrarily assumed the double of the URENCO module. Only (but still approximate) information available for TENEX facility is the electricity consumption by machines of two recent generations. A mix of generations has been assumed here, assuming conservatively a high value for auxiliary electricity (i.e., not directly used for spinning the centrifuges). The Russian electricity mix is used, which has been has been approximated using existing ecoinvent v2.0 electricity datasets for Europe. The factor for the infrastructure requirement is calculated with annual throughput of 1500 t SWU for 30 years operation (the Russian facilities are larger but this should not affect much the figures normalized by the total production).

name: treatment of aluminium scrap, new, at remelter
description:
This dataset is based on two sources: the European Aluminium Association 2005 LCI data (EAA, 2008); and (2) the ecoinvent v2.2 dataset for the same activity (Althaus, 2009), itself largely based on EAA data from 2000.  Priority was given to data contained in EAA (2008); Althaus (2009) was used only in cases where it was found to be more complete that EAA (2008).
Remelters use mainly reverbatory furnaces, and this dataset is based on this furnace technology only.
The dataset excludes, for lack of access to data, salt slag and dross recycling.  According to EAA, this data gap represents approximately 10-20% of potential impacts, as calculated using the CML 2001 method.
The following emissions to air are reported in EAA 2008 but excluded from this dataset: CO (0.095 kg/tonne secondary aluminium), Dust/particulates (0.041 kg/tonne secondary aluminium), NOx (0.329 kg/tonne secondary aluminium), SO2 (0.051 kg/tonne secondary aluminium), and VOC (0.050 kg/tonne secondary aluminium).  These are assumed to be combustion emissions or electricity production emissions, conclusion arrived at by comparing gate-to-gate emissions with the cradle-to-gate emissions also reported in EAA 2008.  Their inclusion wouldhave led to double-counting.
Technology:  Average technology for the aluminium recycled in Europe

name: tellurium production, semiconductor-grade
description:
This datasets describes the production of high-grade tellurium (99.999%) from copper-telluride cementate by hydrometallurgical processes. These hydrometallurgical processes are the dissolving of copper-telluride cementate with sulphuric acid, the following electrolysis and subsequent purification with zone-melting. This purity of tellurium can be used in the production of thin film solar cells.

name: market for palladium
description:
This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.
This is the market for  'palladium', in the Global geography.
Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.

name: uranium fuel element production, enriched 3.8%, for light water reactor
product: uranium, enriched 3.8%, in fuel element for light water reactor
description:
Data for the operation of European nuclear fuel fabrication plants used herewith for China with following differences: Chinese electricity mix; enriched UF6 supply from CNNC centrifuge enrichment plant; transport requirements recalculated either using ecoinvent standard distances for Europe (e.g. for chemicals) or given average distances by train from Chinese 2004 statistics or own assumptions. Modeled in the original dataset is the operation of a plant fabricating UO2 fuel for light water nuclear reactors (PWR and BWR), with no MOX (mixed oxides), no RepU (reprocessed fuel), and no HEU (highly enriched uranium from warheads) fuel elements. Data for the operation of a nuclear fuel fabrication facility are relatively old but emissions to water are complete for a US plant. Radioactive emissions to air and water have been taken or derived from two commercial German facilities: both (one operational, the other closed) exhibit emissions per unit of product fuel much lower than data published in the 1980s. An average value of the two plants is used. Zirconium for cladding is modelled as chromium, for lack of complete information on its metallurgical process; the uncertainty value reflects only the amount. This module is linked with one enrichment module with specific characteristics for the mix or enrichment processes and electricity supply mix; hence, before using the cumulated results of this module the conditions for enrichment should be verified. This dataset has been developed with the goal to serve a preliminary estimation of the Chinese nuclear chain for the Chinese electricity mix. Hence, it cannot be used for comparisons of fuel fabrication among countries.

name: aluminium production, primary, ingot
location: IAI Area, Russia & RER w/o EU27 & EFTA
description:
The dataset represents the production of 1kg of primary aluminium ingot. Molten aluminium produced from the electrolytic process is tapped from reduction cells, weighed, sampled and analysed before it is poured into a holding furnace and heated to approximately 750°C using natural gas as a fuel. Alloying elements, such as magnesium, silicon and manganese, for additional strength, corrosion resistance and other properties, are added to the aluminium. It is typically at this point in the process that clean, sorted scrap can also be added but for the purposes of this dataset, scrap remelting is excluded. During furnace charging and preparation, aluminium dross (a thick liquid or solid phase) forms at the surface of molten aluminium. This mixture of aluminium oxides is remelted to recover the aluminium that would otherwise be lost. Metallurgical analysis verifies that the metal meets customer specifications before the molten, alloyed (or pure, unalloyed) aluminium is cast into products of specific dimensions, before being weighed, bundled and strapped ready for transport. Original dataset included some alloying elements.  These were replaced by liquid aluminium to generate a theoretical 100% aluminium ingot.
For more information on the process, please go to 
http://primary.world-aluminium.org/index.php?id=285

name: aluminium alloy production, Metallic Matrix Composite
description: This dataset represents the manufacturing of aluminium alloyed, metallic matrix composite, billets and ingots. It represents production of ceramic reinforced aluminium alloys. Primary aluminium slab is used as the main aluminium bearing input (75-80%). Scrap aluminium is used as aluminium input up to 20-15%. Aluminium scrap and cold primary slabs and other metal additive are pre-heated in a furnace to remove all trace of water. Powder alloying additives are dried by cycloning with hot air. Aluminium is melt in an induction furnace where aluminium based alloys, silicium carbide and bore carbide powders and pure metals are added to obtain desired alloy composition. Refractory material is used to prevent oxidation of molten aluminium alloy and as coating for mold. Final product is cast by direct chilled vertical casting or ingot mold and allowed to cool down slowly in an oven.

name: titanium dioxide production, sulfate process
description:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of titanium dioxide using concentrated sulfuric acid. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is available as a white powder. It is stable and nontoxic. Titanium dioxide exists in natural minerals (rutile).
This dataset is based on data published by the European Commission (2007).
References:
European Commission (2007) Reference Document on Best Available Techniques for the Manufacture of Large Volume Inorganic Chemicals - Solids and Others industry. Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control. European Commission, Institute for Prospective Technological Studies, Edificio Expo.
Geography:  Average values of European producers. The inventory is assumed to be representative of the global production.
Technology:  The present inventory uses low concentration ore ilmenite. The presence of iron in ilmenite leads to the cogeneration of iron sulfate. The sulfate process consists of the following sequential stages 
1. raw material import and preparation. The ore is stored in covered silos to avoid drying in case it becomes wet. It is then ground using large ball mills to produce particles typically 40-60 um for efficient dissolution with concentrated sulfuric acid. The main emissions at this stage are dust. This is collected by discharging the gas through bag filters. 
2. Digestion: reporting by EU producers indicates operation in batches is commonly used. The ilmenite is mixed with highly concentrated sulfuric acid (80-95%) and this is necessary to digest the feedstock containing TiO2. A highly exothermic reaction is initated by the addition of a measured quantity of steam at around 140°C.  The equation is summarized as: FeTiO3 + 2H2SO4 = TiOSO4 + 2H2O + FeSO4   The off-gases contain small quantities of dust, sulfur dioxide and acid fumes, which are removed by scrubbing. The resulting solid cake is dissolved in water and acid recycled from subsequent washing step. The primary intermediate from the reaction is titanyl suphate (TiOSO4),
3. Reduction: the digester liquor is contacted with scrap iron. This process generates a small amount of H2, which is returned to the air.
4. Clarification and crystallization: titanyl sufate is recovered from the solution and neutralised with lime before going to landfill. This material can be also used as inert filler. The clarified solution is pumped to bacth cooler/crystalisers to remove the bulk of the iron sulfate as the solid heptahydrate 'copperas'. This is widely used in water treatment and other industries. The iron-depleted product liquor is concentrated in evaporators.
5. Hydrolysis (hydrate precipitation). The reaction is:
TiOSO4 + 2H2O = TiO(OH)2 + H2SO4 
Precipitation of the hydrated TiO2 is achieved by boiling the liquor for some hours followed by cooling to 60°C. At this stage of the process, the spenc acid with a concentration of 20-25% H2SO4 and 10-15% soluble salts (mainly iron, aluminium and mangesium sulfates) arises and is either recycled or neutralised with lime to produce gypsum which is preferntially sold at local markets as a commercial product.
6. Calcination: The rotary kilns are directly fired with oil or gas. Scrubbing calciner gas treatment has been upgraded in the past in order to reduce SO2 emissions. SO2 is normally reduced to form sulfuric acid and then recycled in the process. 
7. Finishing. The resulting solid is cooled, milled, coated, washed, dried and micronised.
References:
European Commission (2007) Reference Document on Best Available Techniques for the Manufacture of Large Volume Inorganic Chemicals - Solids and Others industry. Integrated Pollution Prevention and Control. European Commission, Institute for Prospective Technological Studies, Edificio Expo.
Time period:  Reference year of the production volume.

name: market for aluminium removed by drilling, conventional
description:
This is a market activity. In the case of services or immobile infrastructures, markets are connecting suppliers and consumers at a global level. For specific connections at regional level, direct links between the local producing activities and the local consumers are preferred. Transport or losses are logically not relevant for this type of products.
This is the market for  'aluminium removed by drilling, conventional', in the Global geography.
This market contains no transport or losses, as they are irrelevant for the delivered product.
This is delivering the service of 'aluminium removed by drilling, conventional'. Drilling uses a rotating cutting tool (the drill bit) to remove material from the work piece and it predominately uses the front end for cutting. It is applied for shapes like circular cavity or holes. The process is conventional, meaning that it is controlled manually and needs constant supervision. This dataset represents the drilling of 1 kg of aluminium. The service includes materials input, production infrastructure, machinery and electricity consumption. Maintenance and tool (bit) replacements are not included. Degreasing is not included and has to be added if necessary.

name: market for sulfidic tailings, from gold mine operation
product: sulfidic tailings, from gold mine operation
description:
This is a market activity, representing a treatment mix. In the case of products needing treatment, market mixes are supplied by the activities treating the product in the geography defined by the market, and they supply the activities needing to treat the product, as they have generated it as a by-product in the Undefined processes (present as a negative input in system models). Transport to the treating facility or losses are also accounted in this type of markets, when relevant.
This is the market for  'sulfidic tailings, from gold mine operation', in the geography of Canada.
This dataset represents the conveyance of 1 kg of sulfidic tailings generated in a gold mine, from the location in the mine where they are produced to the tailings impoundment.

name: market for aluminium scrap, new
description:
This is a market activity, representing a treatment mix. In the case of products needing treatment, market mixes are supplied by the activities treating the product in the geography defined by the market, and they supply the activities needing to treat the product, as they have generated it as a by-product in the Undefined processes (present as a negative input in system models). Transport to the treating facility or losses are also accounted in this type of markets, when relevant.

Geography:  Some Swiss datasets are used for European processes.
Technology:  Average technology for the aluminium recycled in Europe

name: electricity voltage transformation from high to medium voltage, aluminium industry
description:
This dataset represents the transformation of electricity voltage from high to medium voltage. It is specific to the electricity mix consumed by the aluminium industry in South America. It includes transformation losses. Capital goods are however included in electricity markets.
It is assumed the primary aluminium industry consumes medium voltage electricity.
This dataset represents the transformation of electricity voltage from high to medium voltage.
Definition of the voltage levels:
 - High voltage level above 24 kV (large scale industry)
 - Medium voltage level between 1 kV and 24 kV (medium to small scale industry, service sector
and public buildings)
 - Low voltage level below 1 kV (Households)
Geography:  Aluminium producing South American countries (AR, BR, VE)
Time period:  Production volume updated with 2015 data from IAI

name: iron-nickel-chromium alloy production
description:
Class I nickel as nickel input and ferrochromium (68% Cr) as chromium input used. Scrap is only used as iron bearing input. No nicked or chromium input from the iron scrap assumed.

name: palladium to generic market for metal catalyst for catalytic converter
description:
This activity links palladium to the generic market for metal catalyst for catalytic converter. All metals that enter this market provide the function of a metal catalyst for use in a catalytic converter.
The product "metal catalyst for catalytic converter" should be used only in cases where the specific metal catalyst is not known. Three metals are commonly used as metal catalysts in catalytic converters: palladium, platinum and rhodium. Their function is to reduce the amount of toxic exhaust emissions from the combustion of fuels.

name: processing of anode slime from electrorefining of copper, anode
description:
For the processing of anode slimes from primary copper electrorefining globally.
Background: Metals are produced as part of a complex, highly interconnected and interdependent system, with many desirable but scarce/critical metals recovered as by-products during the production of one or more ‘host’ metal(s). Copper is one of the world’s major mineral commodities and is mined from heterogeneous sulfide or oxide mineral deposits in countries worldwide. Copper sulfide deposits, such as those of the porphyry or massive sulphide type, contain numerous other valuable minerals, which are desirable to society. Copper is mined & beneficiated to produce a copper sulfide concentrate, as well as other by-product concentrates (e.g. molybdenite), which are sold to smelters. Copper sulfide concentrates are smelted to produce the intermediate product, copper anode. This is then sold to refineries, where it is electrorefined to produce copper cathode, which is sold to fabricators. The by-product of copper electrorefining is anode slime, which contains various important by-product metals (principally gold, silver, selenium & tellurium) and is sold to precious metal recovery plants for further processing to recover the valuable metals.
Modelling approach: Amounts of exchanges to the environment and from the technosphere were taken from the treatment activity, “treatment of precious metal from electronics scrap, in anode slime, precious metal extraction”, which was used here as a proxy for the treatment of anode slime from primary copper production via pyrometallurgy. The amounts of by products from the process were calculated through a global material flow analysis of primary copper production. Further information is provided in the accompanying documentation (see Turner & Hischier, 2020). Electrical energy demand was based on Chatterjee et al. (1996).
References
Chatterjee, B. (1996). Electrowinning of gold from anode slimes. Materials Chemistry and Physics, 45, 27-32.
Turner, D. A. & Hischier, R. (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland.
Geography:  Amounts of exchanges to the environment and from the technosphere based on data from a Swedish anode slime processing plant that is singular in the region and ranges worldwide among the big producer. It may be taken as approximation for the global situation. Amounts of by-products based on the typical global situation.
Technology:  Based on typical current technology. Anode slime treatment by pressure leaching and top blown rotary converter. Production of Silver by Möbius Electrolysis, Gold by Wohlwill electrolysis, copper telluride cement and crude selenium to further processing.
Time period:  Production volumes are representative of the situation in 2015 but are considered valid until the end of 2019. Data sources for the inventory model have not been updated since v2.1 (see Classen et al. 2009), but the amounts of by-products have been adjusted to represent the current situation.
References
Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.

name: copper mine operation and beneficiation, sulfide ore
description:
"For the mining and beneficiation of copper sulfide ores in the United States.
Background: Metals are produced as part of a complex, highly interconnected and interdependent system, with many desirable but scarce/critical metals recovered as by-products during the production of one or more ‘host’ metal(s). Copper is one of the world’s major mineral commodities and is mined from heterogeneous sulfide or oxide mineral deposits in countries worldwide. Copper sulfide deposits, such as those of the porphyry or massive sulphide type, contain numerous other valuable minerals, which are desirable to society. Copper is mined & beneficiated to produce a copper sulfide concentrate, as well as other by-product concentrates (e.g. molybdenite), which are sold to smelters. Copper sulfide concentrates are smelted to produce the intermediate product, copper anode. This is then sold to refineries, where it is electrorefined to produce copper cathode, which is sold to fabricators. The by-product of copper electrorefining is anode slime, which contains various important by-product metals (principally gold, silver, selenium & tellurium) and is sold to precious metal recovery plants for further processing to recover the valuable metals. 
Modelling approach: This dataset was created using the life cycle inventory process model described by Classen et al. (2009) and used to generate datasets for ecoinvent v2.1. Typical average ore grades are estimated for each region based on data from Northey et al. (2014), while values for several other key input parameters have been updated since the release of the v2.1 dataset. These include (non-exclusively) the production volumes, beneficiation efficiency (i.e. yield), concentrate grades, anode slime composition (a product of the downstream copper electrorefining processing but that has a direct influence on the properties of exchanges in this dataset), and water outputs. Further information on these changes is provided in the Sampling Procedure comment, as well as the accompanying documentation (see Turner & Hischier, 2020). 
References:
Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.
Northey, S., Mohr, S., Mudd, G. M., Weng, Z., & Giurco, D. (2014). Modelling future copper ore grade decline based on a detailed assessment of copper resources and mining. Resources Conservation and Recycling, 83, 190-201.
Turner, D. A. & Hischier, R. (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland."
Geography:  This dataset is valid for the whole corresponding region. Some agents used, such as lime and sodium cynaide, originate from datasets value for Switzerland or Europe. Processes such as blasting originate from datasets value for Switzerland or Europe. Exchanges amounts calculated based on country-specific average ore grade (as reported in Northey et al. 2014).
References:
Northey, S., Mohr, S., Mudd, G. M., Weng, Z., & Giurco, D. (2014). Modelling future copper ore grade decline based on a detailed assessment of copper resources and mining. Resources Conservation and Recycling, 83, 190-201.
Technology:  Based on typical current technology. Mining is done 70% open pit and 30% underground, followed by joint beneficiation of copper and molybdenite trough flotation, where considerable amounts of agents are added. Overburden is disposed separate to sulfidic tailings near the mining site. No dewatering (or other pre-treatment) of the tailings of is assumed as this is considered a treatment activity that occurs only at selective sites and is therefore modelled separately.
Time period:  Production volumes are representative of the situation in 2015 but are considered valid until the end of 2019. Data sources for the inventory model have not been updated since v2.1 (see Classen et al. 2009), but important model parameters that determine input data to the model have been updated to be consistent with the current situation.
References
Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.

name: aluminium production, primary, cast alloy slab from continuous casting
product: aluminium, primary, cast alloy slab from continuous casting
description: This dataset represents the manufacturing of aluminium cast alloy by direct chilled horizontal continuous casting from primary liquid aluminium. This process can also be used for production of bus bar, anode beams and anode studs for aluminium smelters or substation. Hot liquid primary aluminium transported by truck using crucibles is used as the main aluminium bearing input (90-95%). The liquid aluminium is pre-treated in reverberatory furnace were pre-heated aluminium scrap, aluminum based alloy additives and pure metals are added to obtain desired alloy composition. Scrap aluminium is used as aluminium input up to 5%. Alloy composition represented in this dataset is mainly cast alloy product from the 1xx.x series (minimum 99% aluminium), but alloy composition that can reach up to 5% of final alloy. Molten aluminium alloy is degassed with argon and cast by direct chilled horizontal continuous casting. Final product is cut to the desired length. Duration of casting varies from 2 Tons per hour to 6 Tons per hour depending on end product desired. Wastewater from chilling is treated on site by diffused air filtration and is mainly recirculated in closed-loop. The operations covered by this dataset include: pre-treatment of hot metal, recovery and handling of internal process scrap, batching, alloying, metal treatment, casting operations, sawing and cooling activities, maintenance and repair of plant and equipment, treatment of process air, liquids and solids.

name: treatment of sulfidic tailings, from gold mine operation, tailings impoundment
product: sulfidic tailings, from gold mine operation
description:
This dataset represents the activity of waste disposal of sulfidic tailings, from gold mine operation in a tailings impoundment in Mexico. 
Background: Tailings, a waste material produced during mineral concentration (beneficiation), often contain significant quantities of mobile toxic metals and are typically produced in large quantities. To manage these wastes, tailings are commonly stored behind dammed impoundments, known as tailings ponds. These ponds pose a significant long-term pollution risk as metals may leach out into the surrounding environment, potentially over very long timeframes.
Modelling approach: This dataset was produced using a model developed specifically for assessing the long-term emissions of tailings disposal (see Doka, 2017). The tailings disposal model is based on the modelling framework applied in existing landfill process models used in ecoinvent and is based on a top-down approach. Literature data on measurements of deposited tailings compositions (solids) and measured current concentrations in leachate (liquid) form the basis of the model and are used to characterise pollutant mobility and calculate the currently occurring rate of emissions of the landfill. Heeding chief parameters, such as hydrology, pH development and elemental chemistry, these emissions are then projected into the future. Tailings composition is based on the typical composition of tailings at gold mine sites worldwide; i.e. composition is not region-specific. Land use was calculated following the approach described by Doka (2008). Based on an assumed generic final height of a tailings impoundment of 60 m and an assumed tailings density of 2200 kg/m3, a land area of 7.58E-06 m2 is required per kilogram of sulfidic tailings. The land is assumed to be converted from unknown origin to a disposal site. After an operational phase of 30 years, spontaneous restoration of a consolidated state is assumed to be reached after one hundred years. The total occupation time is therefore 130 years and the land occupation per kilogram tailings is 9.85E-04 m2.
Waste composition (wet, in ppm): H2O 300000; O 621300; H na; C 6145; S 305.88; N 5.0454; P 192.55; B 54.583; Cl 102.61; Br 0.22894; F 772.88; I na; Ag 9.7097; As 61.447; Ba 356.57; Cd 3.9592; Co 10.634; Cr 46.594; Cu 489.41; Hg 0.40262; Mn 142.11; Mo 10.949; Ni 17.077; Pb 155.09; Sb 34.059; Se 4.2887; Sn 26.979; V 142.69; Zn 190.19; Be 1.9806; Sc 13.343; Sr 100.02; Ti 122.75; Tl 2.6154; W 9.3995; Si 39700; Fe 10240; Ca 2631.2; Al 11955; K 2187; Mg 1408.9; Na 1044.1.   //  Share of carbon in waste that is biogenic 0%.
Activity extent: The dataset includes all potential emissions to the environment and land use changes. Input exchanges of infrastructure, materials, energy, and water are not included here but are accounted for in the activity, gold mine operation.
References
Doka, G. (2008). Life Cycle Inventory data of mining waste: Emissions from sulfidic tailings disposal. Zürich, Switzerland: Doka Life Cycle Assessments.
Doka, G. (2017). A model for waste-specific and climate-specific life cycle inventories of tailings impoundments. Zürich, Switzerland: Doka Life Cycle Assessments.
Geography:  Given name of site is 'Gold deposits; Mexico'. Impoundment site with mean annual temperature (MAT) of 25.9804537700696 degC, mean annual precipitation (MAP) of 773.373266961811 mm/year, mean annual actual evaporation (EAT) of 814.16215607 mm/year, and net infiltration of 366.292188926811 mm/year (using half of natural surface evapotranspiration). 
Technology:  This is an inventory for an impoundment of copper ore beneficiation tailings waste. The following assumptions were made concerning technology: final impoundment height is 60 meters; operation phase duration is 30 years; and impoundment leachates are released into the environment untreated.
Time period:  'Data on average composition of tailings and tailings-derived leachates from literature sources published between 1994 and 2017 (mean publication date: 2009±6). Mean annual temperature and precipitation data for 1970-2000 (source: Fick and Hijmans, 2017); mean annual evapotranspiration for 1950-2000 (source: Fekete et al., 2002). Production volume based on world mine production data from the USGS Minerals Yearbook 2015. Transfer coefficients from prospective, tailings-specific model. 
References: 
Fekete, B. M., Vorosmarty, C. J. & Grabs, W. (2002). High-resolution fields of global runoff combining observed river discharge and simulated water balances. Global Biogeochemical Cycles, 16, 15-1 - 15-10.
Fick, S. E. & Hijmans, R. J. (2017). Worldclim 2: New 1-km spatial resolution climate surfaces for global land areas. International Journal of Climatology, 37, 4302-4315.'

name: market for titania slag, 94% titanium dioxide
uranium hexafluoride production
description:
Data are from old but accurate references. The wet process for converting yellowcake U3O8 to uraniumhexafloride UF6 is described. Data for the Sequoyah facility are used, although it has been shut down at the end of 1992, because the wet process is the mostly used worldwide and because of data availability. Particles have been assumed to be between 2.5 and 10 micrometer. Radioactive solid waste has been accurately accounted. Radioactive waste from decommissioning is taken from an old source, which does not differenciate between dry and wet process, and may not reflect current conditions. The non radioactive solid waste given from the used reference is interpreted as ashes, because most probably incineration occurs internally in the factory. However, the consideration of this waste species as “average incineration residue" should be understood as a guess done to cope with missing information on the specific composition.

name: mine construction, gold
description:
This dataset describes the production of 1 unit of gold mine infrastructure. It includes land use and buildings and machinery consumption, as in open pit and underground mining. Data corresponds to Australian mines Kalgoorlie, Jundee, Tanami and Pajingo, which produce only gold. Tanami and Pajingo are underground mines, Kalgoorlie is an open pit mine, and Jundee is both an open pit and underground mine.

name: uranium production, centrifuge, enriched 3.0%
product: uranium, enriched 3.0%, per separative work unit
description:
This module uses a mix of data, some specific for the URENCO facilities taken from environmental reports, some from literature. Due to lack of information on Chinese (Russian) plants, all requirements and emissions are arbitrarily assumed the double of the URENCO module. Hence, the CNNC (TENEX) facility is assumed to consume 80 kWh/SWU. The factor for the infrastructure requirement is calculated with annual throughput of 1500 t SWU for 30 years operation. Transport requirements recalculated either using ecoinvent standard distances for Europe (e.g. for chemicals) or given average distances by train from Chinese 2004 statistivcs or own assumptions. This dataset has been developed with the goal to serve as preliminary estimation of enrichment services to US BWR. Hence, it cannot be used for comparisons of centrifuge enrichment among countries.

name: market for salt tailing from potash mine
description:
This is a market activity, representing a treatment mix. In the case of products needing treatment, market mixes are supplied by the activities treating the product in the geography defined by the market, and they supply the activities needing to treat the product, as they have generated it as a by-product in the Undefined processes (present as a negative input in system models). Transport to the treating facility or losses are also accounted in this type of markets, when relevant. This is the market for ''salt tailing from potash mine'' in the geography of Canada. Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.
Geography:  The disposal mix is country-specific for Canada.
Technology:  The dataset supplies a disposal mix (technology mix) of ''salt tailing from potash mine'' to the respective waste producing activities.

name: market for aluminium removed by milling, small parts
product: aluminium removed by milling, small parts
description:
This is a market activity. In the case of services or immobile infrastructures, markets are connecting suppliers and consumers at a global level. For specific connections at regional level, direct links between the local producing activities and the local consumers are preferred. Transport or losses are logically not relevant for this type of products.
This is the market for  'aluminium removed by milling, small parts', in the Global geography.
This market contains no transport or losses, as they are irrelevant for the delivered product.
This is delivering the service of 'aluminium removed by milling, small parts'. Milling is a chipping process where the piece of the material is fixed to a movable table while the cutting energy is provided by the rotating cutting tool. It is used for complex shaping and it can be applied to metals, wood and plastic materials. This dataset represents the milling of 1kg of aluminium in small parts. The service includes materials input, production infrastructure, energy consumption, water consumption and materials end-of-life. Degreasing is not included and has to be added if necessary.

name: aluminium fluoride production
description:
The functional unit represent 1 kg of solid aluminium fluoride. Large uncertainty of the process data due to weak data on the production process and missing data on process emissions.
[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]
Geography:  Data used has no specific geographical origin (stoechiometry). Average europenan processes for raw materials, transport requirements and electricity mix used.
Technology:  Production by the fluosilicic acid process. Alumina trihydrate is dissolved in fluosilicic acid and then crystallization takes place in a stirred tank. The overall process yield is of 98%. Inventory bases on stoechiometric calculations. The emissions to air (0.2 wt.% of raw material input) and water were estimated using mass balance. Treatment of the waste water in a internal waste water treatment plant assumed.
Time period:  date of published literature

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. name: market for impact extrusion of aluminium, cold, initial surface treatment
product: impact extrusion of aluminium, cold, initial surface treatment
description:
This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.
This is the market for  'impact extrusion of aluminium, cold, initial surface treatment', in the Global geography.
Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.
This is delivering the service of 'impact extrusion of aluminium, cold, initial surface treatment'. Impact extrusion is a manufacturing process that the product is made out of metal slug. It is a type of pressure forming that take advantage of the change in hardness of materials under high pressure. Surface treatment is a part of these process, including bonderizing and degreasing of the metal in room temperature. This dataset represents the surface treatment of 1 kg of aluminium. It is considered as an integral part of the cold impact extrusion dataset and it includes only the electricity consumption during the surface treatment. It can be applied no matter how may strokes the process includes.

name: niobium mine operation and beneficiation, from pyrochlore ore
description:
This dataset refers to the production of 1 kg of (refined) pyrochlore concentrate (63% beneficiated), as a result of the mining and beneficiation activities in Araxa, Brazil. 
Geography:  The Araxa carbonatite complex in Brasil is located about 6 km south of the city of Araxa in the state of Minas Gerais and serves as the largest known niobium reserve in the world. Since the 1960s, the complex has been mined by CBMM (Companhia Brasileira de Metalurgia e Mineracao), being responsible today for more than 80% of the global niobium production. 
Technology:  Open-pit mining is applied and hydraulic excavators are used to extract the ore with different grades, which is transported to stockpiles awaiting homogenization through earth-moving equipment in order to attain the same concentration.
Conveyor belts (3.5 km) are utilized to transport the homogenized ore to the concentration unit.
Initially, the ore passes through a jaw crusher and moves to the ball mills, where the pyrochlore grains (1 mm average diameter) are reduced to diameters less than 0.104 mm. In the ball mills, recycled water is added in order to i) granulate the concentrate and ii) remove the gas from the sintering unit. The granulated ore undergoes i) magnetic separation, where magnetite is removed and is sold as a coproduct and ii) desliming in order to remove fractions smaller than 5μm by utilizing cyclones. Then the ore enters the flotation process - last stage of the beneficiation process – where the pyrochlore particles come into contact with flotation chemicals (hydrochloric & fluorosilic acid, triethylamene and lime), thereby removing the solid fractions and producing pyrochlore concentrate and barite as a coproduct which is also sold. The produced concentrate contains 55% Nb2O5 and 11% water and moves to the sintering unit, via tubes or is transported in bags while the separated and unused minerals enter the tailings dam.
In the sintering unit, the pyrochlore concentrate undergoes pelletizing, sintering, crushing and classification. These units not only accumulate the material but are also responsible for removing sulfur and water from the concentrate. Then the concentrate enters the dephosphorization unit, where phosphorus and lead are removed from the concentrate. The removal of sulphur and phosphorus have to be executed because of the local pyrochlore ore composition. Then the concentrate undergoes a carbothermic reduction by using charcoal and petroleum coke, producing a refined concentrate, 63% Nb2O5 and tailings with high lead content that are disposed in the tailings dam again. 
Time period:  Data are considered representative of current production practices.

name: market for electricity, medium voltage, aluminium industry
location: IAI Area, Russia & RER w/o EU27 & EFTA
description:
This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.
This dataset describes the electricity available on the medium voltage level for aluminium production in the European aluminium producing countries outside the region covered by the European Aluminium Association (EAA), i.e. outside EU27 and EFTA. The actual countries covered by this region are Russia, Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Aluminium industry specific markets are needed in an LCI database because primary aluminium production is very energy intensive, and hence the location of production plants is often determined by access to large amounts of cheap electricity, which often results in an electricity mix that is different from the general grid mix of the countries where the production plants are located.
Geography:  European aluminium producing countries outside the region covered by the European Aluminium Association (EAA), i.e. outside EU27 and EFTA. The actual countries covered by this region are Russia, Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Technology:  Average technology used to transmit and distribute electricity. Includes underground and overhead lines, as well as air-, vacuum- and SF6-insulated high-to-medium voltage switching stations.

name: electricity production, coal, aluminium industry
description:
This is a dataset used to create an aluminium industry specific electricity market for aluminium-producing countries within EU27 and EFTA (see Geography comment field for list of countries). The production volume represents the total amount of electricity from coal used for aluminium production (electrolysis and ingot casting) in the region. The dataset also identifies the technology and country providing the electricity from coal power plants. 
Electricity markets specific to the aluminium-industry are needed in an LCI database because primary aluminium production is very energy intensive, and hence the location of production plants is often determined by access to large amounts of cheap electricity, which often results in an electricity mix that is different from the general grid mix of the countries where the production plants are located. 
It is assumed that the production of electricity in general and in aluminium industry specific power plants is identical. Details on actual electricity generation with each technology can be found in the corresponding datasets.
The share of electricity produced using lignite and hard coal is calculated using both (1) estimates of the share of coal electricity coming from each country within EU27+EFTA; and (2) ecoinvent v3.2 country-specific split of coal power plants between hard coal and lignite. The share of coal electricity in each country was calculated by distributing the total coal electricity used in aluminium production in the EU27+EFTA region (using regional data supplied by the International Aluminium Institute [IAI] and the European Aluminium Association [EAA]). The distribution is weighted by country-specific aluminium production volumes (source: EAA personal communication) and general grid mix in the respective countries (source: International Energy Agency). Exceptions to the general procedure are Greece, Slovakia and Slovania, for which the IAI provided country-specific aluminium-specific grid mixes. 
Calculations are detailed in the report 'Calculating grid mixes for the aluminium industry in ecoinvent v3', available on the ecoinvent website.
Geography:  Aluminium producing European countries within EU27 and EFTA whose aluminium producers are part of the European Aluminium Association (France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia)
Time period:  Production volume updated with 2015 data from IAI

name: mine construction, gold
description:
This dataset describes the production of 1 unit of gold mine infrastructure. It includes land use and building and machinery consumption, as both in underground and surface (i.e. open pits) mining. Data correspond to those operations/plants that operates mostly underground mining and some open pits, specifically: AngloGold Ahanti, Harmony, Sibanye and GoldFields. 
Geography:  Land use of South-African mine, other inputs based on rough assumptions. Most of the mining operation and unrefined gold production activities are in an area called Witwatersrand basin. The are is approximately 350 km long and 200 km wide: the gold mines in this area are possibly  the deepest in the world (mining operation at 3600 m  and explortion core-drilling up to 4600 m.  
MINE DEPTH: Mine depht: South Africa has thin and extensive precious metal reefs often lying several kilometres beneath the earth’s surface and usually slopes dips at up to 20 degrees. The country’s gold and somehow platinum corporations have to sink the deepest mine shafts in the world sometimes close to 4000 m for Gold in depths to reach and extract t he reefs; the  mine depth rages from 2,6 km t up to 4 km beneath the earth’s surface and an average depth is of about 3,335 km.

name: treatment of sulfidic tailings, from gold mine operation, tailings impoundment
product: sulfidic tailings, from gold mine operation
description:
This dataset represents the activity of waste disposal of sulfidic tailings, from gold mine operation in a tailings impoundment. 
Background: Tailings, a waste material produced during mineral concentration (beneficiation), often contain significant quantities of mobile toxic metals and are typically produced in large quantities. To manage these wastes, tailings are commonly stored behind dammed impoundments, known as tailings ponds. These ponds pose a significant long-term pollution risk as metals may leach out into the surrounding environment, potentially over very long timeframes.
Modelling approach: This dataset was produced using a model developed specifically for assessing the long-term emissions of tailings disposal (see Doka, 2017). The tailings disposal model is based on the modelling framework applied in existing landfill process models used in ecoinvent and is based on a top-down approach. Literature data on measurements of deposited tailings compositions (solids) and measured current concentrations in leachate (liquid) form the basis of the model and are used to characterise pollutant mobility and calculate the currently occurring rate of emissions of the landfill. Heeding chief parameters, such as hydrology, pH development and elemental chemistry, these emissions are then projected into the future. Tailings composition is based on the typical composition of tailings at gold mine sites worldwide; i.e. composition is not region-specific. Land use was calculated following the approach described by Doka (2008). Based on an assumed generic final height of a tailings impoundment of 60 m and an assumed tailings density of 2200 kg/m3, a land area of 7.58E-06 m2 is required per kilogram of sulfidic tailings. The land is assumed to be converted from unknown origin to a disposal site. After an operational phase of 30 years, spontaneous restoration of a consolidated state is assumed to be reached after one hundred years. The total occupation time is therefore 130 years and the land occupation per kilogram tailings is 9.85E-04 m2.
Waste composition (wet, in ppm): H2O 300000; O 621300; H na; C 6145; S 305.88; N 5.0454; P 192.55; B 54.583; Cl 102.61; Br 0.22894; F 772.88; I na; Ag 9.7097; As 61.447; Ba 356.57; Cd 3.9592; Co 10.634; Cr 46.594; Cu 489.41; Hg 0.40262; Mn 142.11; Mo 10.949; Ni 17.077; Pb 155.09; Sb 34.059; Se 4.2887; Sn 26.979; V 142.69; Zn 190.19; Be 1.9806; Sc 13.343; Sr 100.02; Ti 122.75; Tl 2.6154; W 9.3995; Si 39700; Fe 10240; Ca 2631.2; Al 11955; K 2187; Mg 1408.9; Na 1044.1.   //  Share of carbon in waste that is biogenic 0%.
Activity extent: The dataset includes all potential emissions to the environment and land use changes. Input exchanges of infrastructure, materials, energy, and water are not included here but are accounted for in the activity, gold mine operation.
References
Doka, G. (2008). Life Cycle Inventory data of mining waste: Emissions from sulfidic tailings disposal. Zürich, Switzerland: Doka Life Cycle Assessments.
Doka, G. (2017). A model for waste-specific and climate-specific life cycle inventories of tailings impoundments. Zürich, Switzerland: Doka Life Cycle Assessments.
Geography:  Given name of site is 'Gold deposits; Global'. Impoundment site with mean annual temperature (MAT) of 11.5488718087177 degC, mean annual precipitation (MAP) of 1218.22781426197 mm/year, mean annual actual evaporation (EAT) of 580.647365158709 mm/year, and net infiltration of 927.904131682617 mm/year (using half of natural surface evapotranspiration). 
Technology:  This is an inventory for an impoundment of copper ore beneficiation tailings waste. The following assumptions were made concerning technology: final impoundment height is 60 meters; operation phase duration is 30 years; and impoundment leachates are released into the environment untreated.
Time period:  'Data on average composition of tailings and tailings-derived leachates from literature sources published between 1994 and 2017 (mean publication date: 2009±6). Mean annual temperature and precipitation data for 1970-2000 (source: Fick and Hijmans, 2017); mean annual evapotranspiration for 1950-2000 (source: Fekete et al., 2002). Production volume based on world mine production data from the USGS Minerals Yearbook 2015. Transfer coefficients from prospective, tailings-specific model. 
References: 
Fekete, B. M., Vorosmarty, C. J. & Grabs, W. (2002). High-resolution fields of global runoff combining observed river discharge and simulated water balances. Global Biogeochemical Cycles, 16, 15-1 - 15-10.
Fick, S. E. & Hijmans, R. J. (2017). Worldclim 2: New 1-km spatial resolution climate surfaces for global land areas. International Journal of Climatology, 37, 4302-4315.'

name: market for mine infrastructure, underground, uranium
description:
This is a market activity. In the case of services or immobile infrastructures, markets are connecting suppliers and consumers at a global level. For specific connections at regional level, direct links between the local producing activities and the local consumers are preferred. Transport or losses are logically not relevant for this type of products.
This is the market for  'mine infrastructure, underground, uranium', in the Global geography.
Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.
This is an immobile infrastructure, representing the construction of a mine infrastructure, underground, uranium. The infrastructure uses U3O8 0.2% with  grade and it has an annual capacity of 2.45E5 kg uranium. If economic open cast mining is impossible (overburden too hard or more than 100 m thick), the uranium ore must be extracted by deep mining. The deposit is opened up by shafts and drifts. In uranium mining, essentially the same technology is used as in conventional mining. The process includes building materials and land use.

name: gold mine operation and gold production, unrefined
description:
This dataset represents the activity of gold production in both underground and surface (open pits) mines in South Africa. The production volume reported , as well as all other inputs/outputs fro the activity itself represent an average gold mining site and don't refer to a specific one. Data was taken from 2015 operational and environmental reports of four different companies, namely: AngloGold Ashanti, Harmony, Sibanye and GoldFields. The annual production volume of the companies investigated accounts for the 73% of the total annual production for the same year (2015). 
Geography:  Most of the mining operation and unrefined gold production activities are in an area called Witwatersrand basin. The are is approximately 350 km long and 200 km wide. the gold mines in this area are possiblu the deepest in the world (mining operation at 3600 m  and explortion core-drilling up to 4600 m. Peak gold production occurred in 1970 when over 1000 metinc tonnes were mined.

name: uranium fuel element production, enriched 4%, for light water reactor
product: uranium, enriched 4%, in fuel element for light water reactor
description:
Modeled is the operation of a plant fabricating UO2 fuel for light water nuclear reactors (PWR and BWR), with no MOX (mixed oxides), no RepU (reprocessed fuel), and no HEU (highly enriched uranium from warheads) fuel elements. Hence the radioactive emissions (and spectrum) as well as the radioactive solid waste may have been somewhat underestimated. Data for the operation of a nuclear fuel fabrication facility are relatively old but emissions to water are complete for a US plant. Radioactive emissions to air and water have been taken or derived from two commercial German facilities: both (one operational, the other closed) exhibit emissions per unit of product fuel much lower than data published in the 1980s. An average value of the two plants is used. Zirconium for cladding is modelled as chromium, for lack of complete information on its metallurgical process; the uncertainty value reflects only the amount. This module is linked with one enrichment module with specific characteristics for the mix or enrichment processes and electricity supply mix; hence, before using the cumulated results of this module the conditions for enrichment should be verified.
[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]
Geography:  North American and European conditions
Technology:  Information regards facilities operating in the 1980s, with few more recent data.

name: aluminium hydroxide production
description:
Data on Al(OH)3 extraction and calcination to Al2O3 was aggregated on original source (International ALuminium Institute 2015 LCI survey, IAI personnal communication in 2017). In- and outputs of Al(OH)3 are calculated according to the stoichiometry (1.530 kg Al(OH)3 --> 1.000 kg Al2O3 + 0.530 kg H2O). Separate energy data was provided by IAI for production of hydrate and calcination processes. The Al(OH)3 extraction process involves adding milled bauxite to a hot caustic soda (NaOH) solution, dissolving the aluminium-bearing minerals (gibbsite, böhmite and diaspore) present to form a sodium aluminate supersaturated solution or “pregnant liquor”. Flocculants are added to aid settling and the solution is progressively cooled causing aluminium hydroxide crystals to precipitate. Further information can be found at http://bauxite.world-aluminium.org/refining/process.html.
Two sources were used in the creation of this dataset: IAI 2015 Survey data (officially published in 2017);  and original ecoinvent 2 data (Althaus, 2007) for exchanges unreported by IAI.
Geography:  While IAI data are global in scope, flows not reported by IAI and taken from anterior ecoinvent v2 dataset are based on European data.
Technology:  Average technology for the global aluminium industry.

name: market for scrap aluminium
description:
This is a market activity, representing a treatment mix. In the case of products needing treatment, market mixes are supplied by the activities treating the product in the geography defined by the market, and they supply the activities needing to treat the product, as they have generated it as a by-product in the Undefined processes (present as a negative input in system models). Transport to the treating facility or losses are also accounted in this type of markets, when relevant. This is the market for 'scrap aluminium' in Global geography. Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.
Geography:  The disposal mix is country-specific for Global geography.
Technology:  The dataset supplies a disposal mix (technology mix) of 'scrap aluminium' to the respective waste producing activities.

name: treatment of bottom ash, MSWI, scrap aluminium, slag compartment
description:
The process represents the treatment of controlled landfilling in slag compartment of a waste (bottom ash) that is exclusively generated in another waste treatment. Bottom ash is the by-product that is generated during the municipal solid waste incineration (MSWI) of 'scrap aluminium'. Recommended use of this dataset: to be used within the specific chain of treatments for 'scrap aluminium'. Share of biogenic carbon in the sludge: 0%.
Geography:  Modelling parameters affecting the treatment technology are not specific to this geography.
Technology:  Slag compartment for bottom ash from incineration with base seal and leachate collection system (Landfill type D). Recultivation after closure.

name: aluminium production, primary, liquid, prebake
description: Geography:  Data mostly from global surveys by IAI.

name: market for aluminium oxide, metallurgical
description:
This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.
This is the market for  'aluminium oxide, metallurgical', in the Global geography.
This activity represents the market for 1kg of aluminium oxide, metallurgical. The distances were calculated using the total alumina transport for both Söderberg and prebake electrolysis (in tkm/t liquid aluminium), the amount of alumina (t/t aluminium) and the relative production volume of Söderberg and prebake electrolysis.
[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

name: uranium production, centrifuge, enriched 3.9%
product: uranium, enriched 3.9%, per separative work unit
description:
This module uses a mix of data, some specific for the URENCO facilities taken from environmental reports, some from literature. Due to lack of information on Russian plants, all requirements and emissions are arbitrarily assumed the double of the URENCO module. Only (but still approximate) information available for TENEX facility is the electricity consumption by machines of two recent generations. A mix of generations has been assumed here, assuming conservatively a high value for auxiliary electricity (i.e., not directly used for spinning the centrifuges). The Russian electricity mix is used, which has been has been approximated using existing ecoinvent v2.0 electricity datasets for Europe. The factor for the infrastructure requirement is calculated with annual throughput of 1500 t SWU for 30 years operation (the Russian facilities are larger but this should not affect much the figures normalized by the total production).
[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

Technology:  The technology used for uranium enrichment with centrifuge process in Russia is a mix of three generations of machines.
