name: market for sewage sludge, 70% water, WWT-SLF, waste aluminium
product: sewage sludge, 70% water, WWT-SLF, waste aluminium
description:
This is a market activity, representing a treatment mix. In the case of products needing treatment, market mixes are supplied by the activities treating the product in the geography defined by the market, and they supply the activities needing to treat the product, as they have generated it as a by-product in the Undefined processes (present as a negative input in system models). Transport to the treating facility or losses are also accounted in this type of markets, when relevant. This is the market for 'sewage sludge, 70% water, WWT-SLF, waste aluminium' in the geography of Switzerland. Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.
Geography:  The disposal mix is country-specific for Switzerland.
Technology:  The dataset supplies a disposal mix (technology mix) of 'sewage sludge, 70% water, WWT-SLF, waste aluminium' to the respective waste producing activities.

name: copper mine operation and beneficiation, sulfide ore
description:
"For the mining and beneficiation of copper sulfide ores globally.
Background: Metals are produced as part of a complex, highly interconnected and interdependent system, with many desirable but scarce/critical metals recovered as by-products during the production of one or more ‘host’ metal(s). Copper is one of the world’s major mineral commodities and is mined from heterogeneous sulfide or oxide mineral deposits in countries worldwide. Copper sulfide deposits, such as those of the porphyry or massive sulphide type, contain numerous other valuable minerals, which are desirable to society. Copper is mined & beneficiated to produce a copper sulfide concentrate, as well as other by-product concentrates (e.g. molybdenite), which are sold to smelters. Copper sulfide concentrates are smelted to produce the intermediate product, copper anode. This is then sold to refineries, where it is electrorefined to produce copper cathode, which is sold to fabricators. The by-product of copper electrorefining is anode slime, which contains various important by-product metals (principally gold, silver, selenium & tellurium) and is sold to precious metal recovery plants for further processing to recover the valuable metals. 
Modelling approach: This dataset was created using the life cycle inventory process model described by Classen et al. (2009) and used to generate datasets for ecoinvent v2.1. Typical average ore grades are estimated for each region based on data from Northey et al. (2014), while values for several other key input parameters have been updated since the release of the v2.1 dataset. These include (non-exclusively) the production volumes, beneficiation efficiency (i.e. yield), concentrate grades, anode slime composition (a product of the downstream copper electrorefining processing but that has a direct influence on the properties of exchanges in this dataset), and water outputs. Further information on these changes is provided in the Sampling Procedure comment, as well as the accompanying documentation (see Turner & Hischier, 2020). 
References:
Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.
Northey, S., Mohr, S., Mudd, G. M., Weng, Z., & Giurco, D. (2014). Modelling future copper ore grade decline based on a detailed assessment of copper resources and mining. Resources Conservation and Recycling, 83, 190-201.
Turner, D. A. & Hischier, R. (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland."
Geography:  This dataset is valid for the whole corresponding region. Some agents used, such as lime and sodium cynaide, originate from datasets value for Switzerland or Europe. Processes such as blasting originate from datasets value for Switzerland or Europe. Exchanges amounts calculated based on country-specific average ore grade (as reported in Northey et al. 2014).
References:
Northey, S., Mohr, S., Mudd, G. M., Weng, Z., & Giurco, D. (2014). Modelling future copper ore grade decline based on a detailed assessment of copper resources and mining. Resources Conservation and Recycling, 83, 190-201.
Technology:  Based on typical current technology. Mining is done 70% open pit and 30% underground, followed by joint beneficiation of copper and molybdenite trough flotation, where considerable amounts of agents are added. Overburden is disposed separate to sulfidic tailings near the mining site. No dewatering (or other pre-treatment) of the tailings of is assumed as this is considered a treatment activity that occurs only at selective sites and is therefore modelled separately.
Time period:  Production volumes are representative of the situation in 2015 but are considered valid until the end of 2019. Data sources for the inventory model have not been updated since v2.1 (see Classen et al. 2009), but important model parameters that determine input data to the model have been updated to be consistent with the current situation.
References
Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.

name: cobalt production
description:
This dataset represents the production of cobalt by the global cobalt industry. Reference: "The Environmental Performance of Refined Cobalt - Life Cycle Inventory and Life Cycle Assessment of Refined Cobalt - Summary Report", CDI & ERM, Novermber 2016. PM2.5-10 and PM10 emissions to air arise from mine ventillation systems.
Geography:  The data has been collected from a globally representative sample of companies in the cobalt industry.
Technology:  Cobalt, as a co-product of nickel and copper production, is obtained using a wide range of technologies. The initial life cycle stage covers the mining of the ore through underground or open cast methods. The ore is further processed in beneficiation to produce a concentrate and/or raffinate solution. Metal selection and further concentration is initiated in primary extraction, which may involve calcining, smelting, high pressure leaching, and other processes. The final product is obtained through further refining, which may involve processes such as re-leaching, selective solvent / solution extraction, selective precipitation, electrowinning, and other treatments. Transport is reported separately and consists of only the internal movements of materials / intermediates, and not the movement of final product. Due to its intrinsic value, cobalt has a high recycling rate. However, much of this recycling takes place downstream through the recycling of alloy scrap into new alloy, or goes into the cobalt chemical sector as an intermediate requiring additional refinement. Secondary production, ie production from the recycling of cobalt-containing wastes, is considered in this study in so far as it occurs as part of the participating companies’ production. This was shown to be of very limited significance (less than 1% of cobalt inputs). The secondary materials used for producing cobalt are modelled as entering the system free of environmental burden.
Time period:  Data were collected in 2012

name: aluminium oxide production
description:
Data on Al(OH)3 extraction and calcination to Al2O3 was aggregated on original source (IAI 2015, IAI personnal communication 2017). In- and outputs of AL(OH)3 are calculated according to the stoichiometry (1.530 kg Al(OH)3 --> 1.000 kg Al2O3 + 0.530 kg H2O). Separate energy data was provided by IAI for production of hydrate and calcination processes.
Two sources were used in the creation of this dataset: IAI 2015 Survey data; and original ecoinvent 2 data (Althaus, 2007) for flows unreported by IAI.
As reported by the IAI: "Total alumina production is the quantity of aluminium oxide trihydrate produced in a defined period and expressed as 100%, nominal aluminium oxide (Al2O3) equivalent, irrespective of further processing. Total alumina production figures have two components, that to be used for the production of aluminium (metallurgical grade alumina) and that to be used for any other purpose (chemical grade alumina)." (IAIA, 2019, ALUMINA PRODUCTION. Retrieved from: http://www.world-aluminium.org/statistics/alumina-production/, accesseed 11 Feb 2019).
Geography:  While IAI data are global in scope, flows not reported by IAI and taken from anterior ecoinvent v2 dataset are based on European data.
Technology:  Average technology for the aluminium produced globally.

name: uranium fuel element production, enriched 3.0%, for light water reactor
product: uranium, enriched 3.0%, in fuel element for light water reactor
description:
Dataset is identical to datasets with similar name for European nuclear energy chains, with teh notable difference of using the US electricity mix. Modeled is the operation of a plant fabricating UO2 fuel for light water nuclear reactors (PWR and BWR), with only fresh uranium, although US plants may use HEU (highly enriched uranium from warheads) from Russia. Data for the operation of a nuclear fuel fabrication facility are relatively old but emissions to water are complete for a US plant. Radioactive emissions to air and water have been taken or derived from two commercial German facilities: both (one operational, the other closed) exhibit emissions per unit of product fuel much lower than data published in the 1980s. An average value of the two plants is used. Zirconium for cladding is modelled as chromium, for lack of complete information on its metallurgical process; the uncertainty value reflects only the amount. This module is linked with one enrichment module with specific characteristics for the mix or enrichment processes and electricity supply mix; hence, before using the cumulated results of this module the conditions for enrichment should be verified.
[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]
Geography:  North American and European conditions
Technology:  Information regards facilities operating in the 1980s, with few more recent data.

name: aluminium hydroxide production
description:
Data on Al(OH)3 extraction and calcination to Al2O3 was aggregated on original source (International ALuminium Institute 2015 LCI survey, IAI personnal communication in 2017). In- and outputs of Al(OH)3 are calculated according to the stoichiometry (1.530 kg Al(OH)3 --> 1.000 kg Al2O3 + 0.530 kg H2O). Separate energy data was provided by IAI for production of hydrate and calcination processes. The Al(OH)3 extraction process involves adding milled bauxite to a hot caustic soda (NaOH) solution, dissolving the aluminium-bearing minerals (gibbsite, böhmite and diaspore) present to form a sodium aluminate supersaturated solution or “pregnant liquor”. Flocculants are added to aid settling and the solution is progressively cooled causing aluminium hydroxide crystals to precipitate. Further information can be found at http://bauxite.world-aluminium.org/refining/process.html.
Two sources were used in the creation of this dataset: IAI 2015 Survey data (officially published in 2017);  and original ecoinvent 2 data (Althaus, 2007) for exchanges unreported by IAI.
Geography:  While IAI data are global in scope, flows not reported by IAI and taken from anterior ecoinvent v2 dataset are based on European data.
Technology:  Average technology for the global aluminium industry.

name: chlorine, for reuse in titanium tetrachloride production, to generic market for chlorine
description:
This activity links chlorine, obtained from the electrolysis of magnesium chloride that is produced during the production of titanium sponge, to the market for chlorine, liquid.
As the chlorine that is recovered through the electrolysis of magnesium chloride is exclusively reused for the production of titanium tetrachloride, it is assumed that it actually does not supply the market for chlorine. For this reason, the production volume is a dummy value.
The purpose of this activity is to link the recovered chlorine to the market for "chlorine, liquid" in the Consequential system model. In that system model, the activities that are consuming chlorine recovered through the electrolysis of magnesium chloride get instead supplied by the marginal suppliers of chlorine, liquid.

name: aluminium alloy production, Metallic Matrix Composite
description: This dataset represents the manufacturing of aluminium alloyed, metallic matrix composite, billets and ingots. It represents production of ceramic reinforced aluminium alloys. Primary aluminium slab is used as the main aluminium bearing input (75-80%). Scrap aluminium is used as aluminium input up to 20-15%. Aluminium scrap and cold primary slabs and other metal additive are pre-heated in a furnace to remove all trace of water. Powder alloying additives are dried by cycloning with hot air. Aluminium is melt in an induction furnace where aluminium based alloys, silicium carbide and bore carbide powders and pure metals are added to obtain desired alloy composition. Refractory material is used to prevent oxidation of molten aluminium alloy and as coating for mold. Final product is cast by direct chilled vertical casting or ingot mold and allowed to cool down slowly in an oven.

name: electricity voltage transformation from high to medium voltage, aluminium industry
description:
This dataset represents the transformation of electricity voltage from high to medium voltage. It is specific to the electricity mix consumed by the aluminium industry in Africa. It includes transformation losses. Capital goods are however included in electricity markets.
It is assumed the primary aluminium industry consumes medium voltage electricity.
This dataset represents the transformation of electricity voltage from high to medium voltage.
Definition of the voltage levels:
 - High voltage level above 24 kV (large scale industry)
 - Medium voltage level between 1 kV and 24 kV (medium to small scale industry, service sector
and public buildings)
 - Low voltage level below 1 kV (Households)
Geography:  Aluminium-producing African countries (CM, EG, GH, MZ, NG, ZA)
Time period:  Production volume updated with 2015 data from IAI

name: aluminium turning, primarily roughing, computer numerical controlled
product: aluminium removed by turning, primarily roughing, computer numerical controlled
description:
The reference for turning is 1 kg of metal removed. As there is a large variation from factory to factory with regard to the LCI, it is advised that in case this dataset becomes important in the results, it has to be investigated further if the rough estimations made are applicable or not. If you do not know how much has been removed by turning you can use 0.23kg of this process per kg of final product as an average assumption.

name: nutrient supply from potash salt
description:
This inventory describes the supply of nutrients from ''potash salt'' for fertiliser use. 
No machinery expenditures or emissions to the environment are considered related to the actual application of this substance on soil during its agricultural use. The purpose of this activity is to connect the chemical production of ''potash salt'' with its generic use as fertilizer. The product ''potash salt'' is connected to the generic market for ''inorganic potassium fertiliser, as K2O'' through this supplying activity. In the agricultural context, ''potash salt'' can be used directly as a fertilizer input to crop production, eventually with other chemicals; alternatively, a generic input of ''inorganic potassium fertiliser, as K2O'' can be used instead, and this will represent the regional consumption mix for his type of nutrient. A way in between is allowed by using the generic input ''inorganic potassium fertiliser, as K2O'' and link to the activity providing it from a specific chemical.
 In all cases, emissions associated to the application of the fertilizer have to be calculated in the crop production activity.
Image: https://db3.ecoinvent.org/images/e8342b95-78fd-4a83-a444-47e7464508b4
Technology:  Inventory based on composition of ''potash salt''.

name: smelting and refining of nickel concentrate, 7% Ni
description:
This dataset is based on the following publication:  Deng, S. Y., & Gong, X. Z. (2018). Life Cycle Assessment of Nickel Production in China. Materials Science Forum, 913, 1004-1010. doi:10.4028/www.scientific.net/MSF.913.1004 . Specific modifications were made in order to make the dataset more transparent.The publication deals with the pyrometallurgical production of electrolytic nickel (99.98% concentrated) by sulfide ore (1% concentration). This activity represents the production of nickel class I  (99.98% purity)  from nickel concentrate (6.78% concentration).   
Geography:  Dataset valid for the entire corresponding region.
Technology:  The nickel concentrate (6.78% beneficiated - product of the mining and beneficiation processes) undergoes drying, melting in flash furnace and converting to produce high nickel matte. The nickel matte undergoes grinding-floating separation and is refined through anode plate casting and electrolysis in order to produce electrolytic nickel 99.98% pure. Deng, S. Y., & Gong, X. Z. (2018). Life Cycle Assessment of Nickel Production in China. Materials Science Forum, 913, 1004-1010. doi:10.4028/www.scientific.net/MSF.913.1004
Time period:  Data are considered representative of current production practices.

name: clinker production
description:
This dataset represents the production of 1 kg clinker in Ecuador. Clinker is the main constituent of cement and the main responsible for its environmental impacts. The data is obtained for the year 2019 from the publication of Petroche & Ramirez (2022), based on information from factories. 
Reference: 
Petroche, D. M., & Ramirez, A. D. (2022). The Environmental Profile of Clinker, Cement, and Concrete: A Life Cycle Perspective Study Based on Ecuadorian Data. Buildings, 12(3), 311.
Geography:  This dataset is representative of the production of clinker in Ecuador. 
Technology:  Current technology. Clinker is made by heating at high temperature in a rotary kiln a mixture of limestone and clays. In the production of clinker, 86% of the total raw materials are composed of limestone. Four types of clays are used, which come from different parts of 
Ecuador; these clays represent 11% by mass, and other raw materials of mineral correction 
represent 3%.
Time period:  The time period is 2019 (year of the data collection) to 2023 (year of the compilation of the dataset).

name: market for chlorine, for reuse in titanium tetrachloride production
product: chlorine, for reuse in titanium tetrachloride production

name: market for bottom ash, MSWI, scrap aluminium
description:
This is a market activity, representing a treatment mix. In the case of products needing treatment, market mixes are supplied by the activities treating the product in the geography defined by the market, and they supply the activities needing to treat the product, as they have generated it as a by-product in the Undefined processes (present as a negative input in system models). Transport to the treating facility or losses are also accounted in this type of markets, when relevant. This is the market for 'bottom ash, MSWI, scrap aluminium' in the geography of Europe without Switzerland. Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.
Geography:  The disposal mix is country-specific for Europe without Switzerland.
Technology:  The dataset supplies a disposal mix (technology mix) of 'bottom ash, MSWI, scrap aluminium' to the respective waste producing activities.

name: electricity production, coal, aluminium industry
description:
This is a dataset used to create an aluminium industry specific electricity market for 'International Aluminium Institute (IAI) aluminium production Area 1' (Africa). The production volume represents the total amount of electricity from coal used in Area 1 (Africa) for aluminium production (electrolysis and ingot casting). 
Electricity markets specific to the aluminium-industry are needed in an LCI database because primary aluminium production is very energy intensive, and hence the location of production plants is often determined by access to large amounts of cheap electricity, which often results in an electricity mix that is different from the general grid mix of the countries where the production plants are located. 
It is assumed that the production of electricity in general and in aluminium industry specific power plants is identical. Details on actual electricity generation with each technology can be found in the corresponding datasets.
The share of electricity produced using lignite and hard coal is calculated using both (1) estimates of the share of coal electricity coming from each country within Area 1; and  (2) ecoinvent v3.2 country-specific split of coal power plants between hard coal and lignite. The share of coal electricity in each country was calculated by distributing the total coal electricity used in aluminium production in Area 1 (Africa) region as reported by the International Aluminium Institute (IAI). The distribution is weighted by country-specific aluminium production volumes (source: IAI personal communication) and general grid mix in the respective countries (source: International Energy Agency). 
For countries whose electricity production is not modelled in ecoinvent (all but South Africa [ZA] for Area 1), coal-based electricity is assumed to be 78% hard coal, 22% lignite (based on 'rest of world' data, i.e. on data representing all regions not covered in ecoinvent v3.2).
Calculations are detailed in the report 'Calculating grid mixes for the aluminium industry in ecoinvent v3', available on the ecoinvent website.
Geography:  Aluminium-producing African countries (CM, EG, GH, MZ, NG, ZA)
Time period:  Production volume updated with 2015 data from IAI

name: silver-gold mine operation with refinery
description:
This dataset describes the joint production of 112000 kg of silver and 2990 kg of gold. Data was taken from the environmental report of Placer Dome Inc. for La Coipa Mine, an open pit one. Since the mine has been sold in 2006 to Kinross Gold Corporation and Goldcorp Inc., no more recent data is available. Also, both enterprises do not publish their environmental data. Therefore, the older data from 2002 is used to model the gold- and silver production in Chile. 
[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]
Geography:  Material requirements are estimated with Australian data
Technology:  OPEN PIT MINING:
The ore is mined in four steps: drilling, blasting, loading and hauling. In the case of a surface mine, a pattern of holes is drilled in the pit and filled with explosives. The explosives are detonated in order to break up the ground so large shovels or front-end loaders can load it into haul trucks.
BENEFICIATION:
The processing plant consists of primary crushing, a pre-crushing circuit, (semi autogenous ball mill crushing) grinding, leaching, filtering and washing, Merrill-Crowe plant and doré refinery. The Merrill-Crowe metal recovery circuit is better than a carbon-in-pulp system for the high-grade silver material. Tailings are filtered to recover excess water as well as residual cyanide and metals. A dry tailings disposal system was preferred to a conventional wet tailings impoundment because of site-specific environmental considerations.
Time period:  Period of public environmental report

name: market for uranium enrichment diffusion facility
description:
This is a market activity. In the case of services or immobile infrastructures, markets are connecting suppliers and consumers at a global level. For specific connections at regional level, direct links between the local producing activities and the local consumers are preferred. Transport or losses are logically not relevant for this type of products.
This is the market for  'uranium enrichment diffusion facility', in the Global geography.
This market contains no transport or losses, as they are irrelevant for the delivered product.
This is an immobile infrastructure, representing the construction of an uranium enrichment diffusion facility. The facility has capacity of 8,750 tons SWU (separative work unit). The process includes land use, energy (electricity, diesel, and light oil) and material requirements for the construction of the facility and decommission.

name: market for aluminium oxide, non-metallurgical
description:
This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.
This is the market for 'aluminium oxide, non-metallurgical', in the geography of IAI Area, EU27 & EFTA. This is a constrained market for consequential system model, for attributional system models, this is a regular market. In the case of consequential system model, details about the marginal consumer can be found in the comment of the conditional exchange (by-product).
This activity represents the market for 1kg of aluminium oxide, non metallurgical. The transport distances are from the ecoinvent Global transport model, accessible on the ecoinvent website https://www.ecoinvent.org/
This is a constrained market. The justification is included in the comment field of the conditional exchange.
[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

name: market for impact extrusion of aluminium, deformation stroke
product: impact extrusion of aluminium, deformation stroke
description:
This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.
This is the market for  'impact extrusion of aluminium, deformation stroke', in the Global geography.
Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.
This is delivering the service of 'impact extrusion of aluminium, deformation stroke'. Impact extrusion is a manufacturing process that the product is made out of metal slug. It is a type of pressure forming that take advantage of the change in hardness of materials under high pressure. The use of multiple strokes is possible, to produce complex shapes. Strokes deformation is of minor importance when only a single stroke is needed. However, a piece with multiple strokes can significally increase the energy intensity of the process. This dataset represents the stroke deformation of 1 kg aluminium and it only includes the electricity consumption of the machine during the deformation .

name: uranium enrichment centrifuge facility construction
description:
The material and energy requirements for construction have been roughly estimated on the basis of the data from an old US reference and scaling them down by the ratio of the capacities (centrifuge process is modular, therefore in first approximation linearity can be assumed for requirements). It is assumed that 75% of reinforced concrete is dumped as non-contaminated waste from decommissioning.

name: processing of anode slime from electrorefining of copper, anode
description:
For the processing of anode slimes from primary copper electrorefining globally.
Background: Metals are produced as part of a complex, highly interconnected and interdependent system, with many desirable but scarce/critical metals recovered as by-products during the production of one or more ‘host’ metal(s). Copper is one of the world’s major mineral commodities and is mined from heterogeneous sulfide or oxide mineral deposits in countries worldwide. Copper sulfide deposits, such as those of the porphyry or massive sulphide type, contain numerous other valuable minerals, which are desirable to society. Copper is mined & beneficiated to produce a copper sulfide concentrate, as well as other by-product concentrates (e.g. molybdenite), which are sold to smelters. Copper sulfide concentrates are smelted to produce the intermediate product, copper anode. This is then sold to refineries, where it is electrorefined to produce copper cathode, which is sold to fabricators. The by-product of copper electrorefining is anode slime, which contains various important by-product metals (principally gold, silver, selenium & tellurium) and is sold to precious metal recovery plants for further processing to recover the valuable metals.
Modelling approach: Amounts of exchanges to the environment and from the technosphere were taken from the treatment activity, “treatment of precious metal from electronics scrap, in anode slime, precious metal extraction”, which was used here as a proxy for the treatment of anode slime from primary copper production via pyrometallurgy. The amounts of by products from the process were calculated through a global material flow analysis of primary copper production. Further information is provided in the accompanying documentation (see Turner & Hischier, 2020). Electrical energy demand was based on Chatterjee et al. (1996).
References
Chatterjee, B. (1996). Electrowinning of gold from anode slimes. Materials Chemistry and Physics, 45, 27-32.
Turner, D. A. & Hischier, R. (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland.
Geography:  Amounts of exchanges to the environment and from the technosphere based on data from a Swedish anode slime processing plant that is singular in the region and ranges worldwide among the big producer. It may be taken as approximation for the global situation. Amounts of by-products based on the typical global situation.
Technology:  Based on typical current technology. Anode slime treatment by pressure leaching and top blown rotary converter. Production of Silver by Möbius Electrolysis, Gold by Wohlwill electrolysis, copper telluride cement and crude selenium to further processing.
Time period:  Production volumes are representative of the situation in 2015 but are considered valid until the end of 2019. Data sources for the inventory model have not been updated since v2.1 (see Classen et al. 2009), but the amounts of by-products have been adjusted to represent the current situation.
References
Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.

name: treatment of scrap aluminium, municipal incineration
description:
The process represents the treatment of 'scrap aluminium' in a municipal solid waste incinerator (MSWI). Recommended use of this dataset:  for disposal of bulky, non-dust aluminium, which goes to disposal as part of a larger item or in small amounts only. Pure, isolated aluminium fractions will not be disposed in incinerators or landfills, but rather go to recycling. Inventoried waste consists of fraction: 100% Alu in MSW; .Waste composition (wet, in ppmw): H2O na; O na; H na; C na; S na; N na; P na; B na; Cl 4825; Br na; F na; I na; Ag na; As na; Ba na; Cd 3; Co na; Cr na; Cu 8.5; Hg na; Mn na; Mo na; Ni na; Pb 25.5; Sb na; Se na; Sn na; V na; Zn 29; Be na; Sc na; Sr na; Ti na; Tl na; W na; Si na; Fe na; Ca na; Al 995110; K na; Mg na; Na na.Share of carbon in initial waste input that is biogenic 61.4%.Share of metals in waste not oxidised and bulk-recyclable (exclude very small or thin parts) Iron: 0%; Alu: 100%; Copper: 0%.Recovery of metal scrap from bottom ash to recycling: 0g iron scrap, 308.48g aluminium scrap, 0g copper scrap. Net energy production: 0MJ/kg electric energy and 0MJ/kg thermal energy.
Geography:  Modelling parameters affecting the treatment technology are not specific to this geography.
Technology:  The waste is treated in the incineration plant with flue gas cleaning. Incineration is the controlled combustion of a waste. Auxiliary material consumption for this step of air pollution control (APC) are included in the process. Air polution control includes electrostatic precipitator for fly ash (ESP), wet flue gas scrubber and 25%  SNCR , 42.77%  SCR-high dust , 32.68%  SCR-low dust -DeNOx facilities and 0% without DeNOx  (weighted according to mass of burnt waste). Efficiency of iron scrap separation from slag : 58%. Efficiency of aluminium scrap separation from slag : 31%. Efficiency of copper scrap separation from slag : 31%. Gross electric efficiency technology mix 15.84% and Gross thermal efficiency technology mix 28.51%

name: casting, aluminium, lost-wax
description:
This dataset represents the service of casting of aluminium parts using the lost-wax casting, or investment casting, method. This method is one of the oldest known metal working technics. While sand casting is the most frequently use casting technic, lost-wax casting is used for small, up to 32 kg, and precision parts, for exmple for the aeronautical sector. Although more expensive and intensive than sand casting or die casting, it requires less machining and surface finishing. Dataset represenst casting of 1 kg of aluminium and aluminum low-alloy parts by lost-wax casting. It includes materials and energy inputs, waste and emissions. Infrastructure are estimated. Production of metal in final part is excluded, only aluminum associated with losses and its waste management is included. Losses are estimated at 26.1% of aluminium input (or 35.3% of cast product), 97.5% are sent to recycling, the rest is lost in waste sludge.
Geography:  Global dataset extrapolated from regional one.

"'ilmenite, 54% titanium dioxide' is a metal. It has 54% titanium dioxide content. It is a direct product of mining and beneficiation and a by-product from heavy mineral sand quarry operation. It can be used in the following applications and/or processes: production of alloys used in aircraft parts, artificial joints for humans, and sporting equipment such as bicycle frames, also used to produce titanium metal, produce synthetic rutile, a form of titanium dioxide, used to produce white, highly reflective pigments, used to make titanium dioxide, an inert, white, highly reflective material, used as a whiting and to make powder for polishing abrasives in a variety of lapidary work that includes rock tumbling, lapping, cabbing, sphere making, and faceting.
"

name: uranium production, centrifuge, enriched 4.0%
product: uranium, enriched 4.0%, per separative work unit
description:
This module uses a mix of data, some specific for the URENCO facilities in Germany, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom taken from environmental reports, some from literature. The plants consume 40 kWh/SWU and the electricity is assumed to be supplied by the local high voltage electricity grid. The factor for the infrastructure requirement is calculated with annual throughput of 1500 t SWU for 30 years operation.
